9D6604076EEF4E0C9258FAA262C593F8.description: Examine Vaudeville as an inspiration for creating dramatizations.

873C40104EEC4D92BD4127A12BA90575.description: Discuss how theatre and drama can connect individuals to culture.

C7DA7550C0EA4993A805437B6E48976B.description: Explore the ideas of the French Revolution through dramatizations.

D3D7A988DFDB451EB24F3F14B6CBFFD9.description: Use drama vocabulary when responding to or sharing opinions about dramatic works.

ED6E0F63F5654149930E6D6C26C4B8C1.description: Observe a variety of dramatic works

CE88791328D34A5CB6F58718EB40CA0A.description: Drama and storytelling traditions existed prior to the colonization of the United States of America, and evolved as more people arrived

6A4AB785FF3D4215981F9718BE4EC315.description: The way in which drama is understood and appreciated has changed throughout history.

E94875F951494D5B86EC4EA2CC2546E4.description: Appreciation of drama can change through active reflection and experience with drama.

0BE607EBA35943DEA015316B5F60EDC2.description: At the turn of the 20th century, American theatre focused on giving characters realistic qualities instead of stereotypical ones

5CBB2AFD04114EB9B7FB54732613FFE9.description: Vaudeville shows from the 1890s to the 1930s included short scenes, magic, contortionists, singers, and dancers

E33A102AB0DC46B8B43D2BD48C2F0E40.description: Vaudeville was a popular American form of theatre that was valued for its light and comedic style

BF31496AB21B4BEF82D909B91F47C769.description: In western societies, women were allowed to act on stage for the first time during the 18th century.

A0F99B04CCE04B938D748521B3E951EF.description: Plays were banned in many areas of the United States during the revolutionary war in order to cut emotional ties to Britain

B53C160B2B1241AB9359B250CAC19E47.description: Before the colonization of the United States of America, the Indigenous people had rich and historical traditions of storytelling, which continue to be celebrated today.

A3D85AB80190462CBB79796346C699E9.description: The proscenium arch was used during the Enlightenment to create a "picture frame" for the audience to look through to create a sense of realism, as seen in The Royal Opera of Versailles

103C0B3786DF4A21A0E2C51AAE203CB4.description: Plays during the French Revolution communicated the ideas of freedom, equality, and brotherhood

05368E4149A74FB19A131486884B0186.description: Theatre connected the people of France to their culture and values during the French Revolution

6A42B18A5F3C414892613C593CC45A2D.description: Greek and Roman playwrights influenced the Enlightenment, including the works of Aeschylus, Sophocles, Aristophanes, and Euripid

920BF4CFEC1F4F7BA86F5ED3F93A0E37.description: Drama vocabulary can be used when responding to and sharing opinions about dramatic works

7C5647B9CC864C8FA85135AFCDE57D27.description: Responses to and appreciation for drama can reflect personal preferences and perspectives

322568283A2749AC95A8716927D7A6A3.description: Appreciation can shape individual artistry, curiosity, and engagement in drama

B694F78775CE48FA8AF531C546026490.description: Appreciation of drama as an art form can change with experience and inform future decisions about participation in drama

9E431479ACAA40FEBEDCB0D23C7E346A.description: Students relate change to historical events and the evolution of dramatic practices

3B005E17B4ED48A0BBC9E0B6FBB2A037.description: Appreciation: Recognizing beauty, goodness, and truth in drama can be developed by understanding the complexity and richness of great dramatic works, the artists who create and perform them, and the historical and cultural contexts from which they originate

9FC18CBAA5294447ADE1F1EEF36BC245.description: Describe how feedback was incorporated to clarify or enhance artistic intention.

6553CB34B0604625B3358FF393B2020E.description: Evaluate the effectiveness of communicating intention in drama.

9899BD9CDA184A89A1B167E41522F885.description: Problem solve to enhance or refine the intention of a dramatization.

BA87E22CD46C4C44BC0C035942735ECA.description: Take creative risks during the process of developing a character, role, or situation

5F8A09006D004C9AB72D92071843D19A.description: Participate in drama activities that explore and challenge creative expression.

6EEB68012D1E4775A896E37A61CF4477.description: Respond to a variety of stimuli in the creation and exploration of dramatic expression.

C38E590186E1464189B049AB3025C7BD.description: Evaluate how adjustments made to the voice and body are appropriate for the ideas expressed

B1E3C21179024A3CAFFC76D0121D79B7.description: Practise sustaining a character's status, intention, or feelings.

97964D77D4164C308C41750160FD3A4E.description: Demonstrate how voice and body can be combined to represent a character, role, or situation

CBC5AF80D1704B098AF3C9CB85064BE8.description: Adjust body, breath, and voice to communicate intention.

EA910B4D6C4745F5BB99940943A5039F.description: Participate as an audience member and as a performer in drama

2CEC4A5B88424C1EB0A970AD5FC0CFEE.description: Collaborate to solve staging or movement challenges in a variety of performance spaces

B312E67B02FB41F4B8532F4FE9EA15B4.description: Rehearse performances before presenting to an audience

F2C85FD074394A768DEAEE775A2C20B3.description: Demonstrate how to follow directions when working in a dramatization

2DEAA795E20542D5B30691E166D6E057.description: Devise a plan that outlines the requirements needed to rehearse and perform a dramatic work.

9642D0836CDD4E5BA9D66989827313AD.description: Demonstrate how intention can be communicated through the structure and organization of a dramatization.

6505B2E7826A4094A2D0FCF69C43EEBD.description: A performer`s intention may emphasize process over product

FEA1F4560B394A748CB977FB2411C0F0.description: Intention can be linked to the purposeful creation, expression, or appreciation of drama.

E9809FFA79644922B1408E6AF6184CFF.description: Intention refers to what a performer means to express

91532001026846D5A1F5B34FAAE0E418.description: Intention becomes evident to the performer and audience when drama has structure and organization.

718B6F09B4E94FAE9FE69B80D1F5FCDA.description: Creative risk taking can include working individually or in groups trying unfamiliar or new techniques working outside of one's comfort zone

AB546ED9D91B4B4BA794D73F91EA3B48.description: Communicating intention can involve creative processes, including decision making in the creation of a dramatization problem solving creative risk taking consideration and implementation of feedback reflection

38E10EB7500241868BCB9B72F676A0A7.description: A performer's artistic intention can be enhanced or refined by viewing, practising, and participating in drama activities

32FD65F5E8FC4631B514A8D01A9D5A4D.description: A variety of stimuli can be used to focus intention, including images music poetry stories props artworks

FD3F2450545F482C94C0E6B5C083B61D.description: A character's perspective, experience, and feelings can be intentionally portrayed in dramatic works.

1BBE9957AA534B8FB6F9F937B9D17B0A.description: A character's intention, point of view, and status can be expressed through body and voice

DA94E913617E49D1A151A82FA4B0D899.description: Dramatic expression can be created intentionally using the body and voice to communicate status, point of view, and perspective.

0A3D9C566D9E4F22BEF673D9D6E50B8E.description: Dramatizations may be interpreted in a way that differs from what the performer intended

EAC96AD9BEBB416EA09066AD3110ABE2.description: Directions for structure and organization can include cues, assigned roles, and use of stage areas

7D586D63255841EFBAAEFE30658AFF9C.description: Structure and organization in a dramatic work can include story structure, with a beginning, problem, and resolution technical elements dramatic forms creating a plan for a dramatization blocking staging choices awareness of the audience points of view, such as firstperson, the audience, or a chosen character rehearsal and performance processes, such as the use of on- and off-stage areas

B86E1C3246574DCA9ECE38A0745C09D3.description: Students express intention as an integral part of artistic expression in drama

FC1532BDD7F746169F4F0C2F0079D1C8.description: Creating and Presenting: Ideas can be represented dramatically through artworks that draw upon foundational knowledge

82723FCCA1A74997BFC9BE9A035537D1.description: Examine various forms of staging presented in live or recorded performances.

493F812C031248278DBA4B643582042A.description: Discuss the advantages and disadvantages of blocking and staging choices.

CC21F70032C04DEF80D1168064569C41.description: Combine body positions and stage areas in the exploration of dramatic action

52921C2B294B49E48E8E98986CCD0CEB.description: Respond to verbal cues that direct movement throughout the nine stage areas

F0EF15ECB63641A9B7202F03E600AD59.description: Incorporate technical elements in a dramatization.

611BF8F2DC184059A145B3061E785A47.description: Participate in vocal and physical warm-ups.

972A95B7FC1040ACA9798BE0BBB0435E.description: Discuss how inefficient vocal and physical habits can impede expression

A3F008FF9C35453DA81F61489C4498D6.description: Evaluate the use of voice in the development of a character, setting, and mood

F7FC091602174A3886FA9DC614BF5243.description: Examine how the voice can be used to develop authentic characters and stereotypes

BC774D6851664686918B26CC42D8BCD6.description: Examine how the voice can support the believability of a character or situation

5457850ECC1646799624B69B45E7CC26.description: Experiment with how the voice can establish mood or setting in a dramatization.

FC3A19EA634B48EBB174D7AC67F9F649.description: Extend vocal production to reflect character

33390AC17E894A1C8A5AEC255C28FF7E.description: Evaluate the balance of voices within an ensemble

3F34228CACB64A689E5F8C3468345EB8.description: Use the voice in unison to communicate intention.

5DFCB32563E04F32A179CABC71D9FDC3.description: Discuss how drama experiences contribute to knowing when and how to use the voice appropriately

1A42E21FAC6544708F5BF46AE6C63570.description: Staging includes the planning and movement of performer(s) on stage

1B4D14EC16C3469C926CC886E08BEC86.description: Staging creates the world of the performance so that the audience can look in

DB28AA4D9E324A6B8B68CFD0C92501CB.description: Staging is the overall design of a performance

B0798016D9A54555A9BD66943C69DDAB.description: Voice work is physical and requires an awareness of body.

7AF4B5C0466E4FA599C1BBAB9EC70946.description: The voice expresses personality, style, and character.

769D43AC02AB445CBA0CCE52F6E73F54.description: The voice can communicate a performer's intention to the audience and other performers

E63702AC0A0749A6888CD4A0734BCD98.description: Voice is a powerful communication tool that can convey the uniqueness of an individual or ensemble.

376D5C5638C948DD8A53C351A28C60D2.description: A director can guide the movement of the performer(s) on stage

C9F48A3C507D4E96950B9415551CB1DA.description: Blocking is a performer's movement and positioning throughout the nine stage areas

E736A0A0A285479383B5C4032AC8D83A.description: Body positions, including full front, profile, and full back, can be used in conjunction with the nine stage areas.

A1B63C46FBBA48888FAAD57032B6802A.description: Downstage refers to the area closest to the audience.

F3335CB521244D8C82408A0F433D2E87.description: The names of the nine stage areas originated from the structure of a raked stage, where the stage tilts toward the audience.

5389939C8C9E47B2BC030DBFD2C61A17.description: There are nine areas of the stage: upstage right upstage centre upstage left centre right centre centre left downstage right downstage centre downstage left

D41B49235C61491D9D33E2F33439F3A0.description: Dramatic tension can be created through the combination of blocking and technical elements

DEF662C81D0442A79ABFB1F6C9E8C353.description: The world of the performance can be created with technical elements, including blocking performers sound sets props costumes lights

B55EBDE7581447438FE37119FDD914E6.description: Staging includes technical elements, dramatic forms, and audience placement

281C6D2E7059429293F32A4AEBA30F4A.description: When staging decisions have a purpose, an audience's experience can be enhanced

18072FCF9ADB4BBC86441C7A7CFA88EE.description: Vocal control requires awareness of body, breath, and release

752E5004C86B4ECF85E732EFA40305CB.description: Vocal hygiene includes efficient projection of voice and voice production.

CA1334AD6FFA41D2A5E7F728190AD6E9.description: By releasing inefficient vocal and physical habits, opportunities for the voice emerge

C773CCEC91FC45B78986130B123DDF77.description: Voice work can include physical and vocal warm-ups.

C623EFBA6CB345308CCFB15C0FF8554F.description: The voice can be used to make a character or situation more believable.

17D7907AA9C64BE58337D4F80F53E7E0.description: The use of voice can evoke an emotional response from others, focus attention, or drive dramatic action

3C3B3C4418F74A2A9BF432363BB844FC.description: Intentional production and projection of the voice can communicate feelings, tension, and ease

F3AB9B1E233B4D1EB4237F185C9596B3.description: The setting in a drama can be a visual or auditory representation of the place in which the dramatic situation occurs

E18F7B4299B04C32B4C8F6EEA555CDF8.description: The mood in a drama refers to the overall emotional quality of a dramatic work

06EC409CB6E048868E09A46A7601EE4C.description: Vocal expression can contribute to establishing the mood or setting of a dramatization

046E648A55B742879B46C564DEE15E76.description: Voice can begin with thought and breath and lead to verbal or nonverbal expression

34FC00B7BE024523857B16F7C0A376D9.description: Balancing voices within an ensemble requires collaboration and compromise

83C1C568CF7E42C9AF91F8259D9B095C.description: Production of voice as an ensemble requires listening to each other for vocal pitch energy tone volume projection articulation pace phrasing

CDB7C33EA61049B2B7D6BEE1CFF151F3.description: Individual and collective use of voice requires adjustments in volume emphasis accent intonation breathing

2F9A013B4BBF435DB02720313D4CE977.description: A voice can be blended with other voices to create a distinguishable tone

C59397D89FE141E6886277CC3EE1A1B3.description: Students associate voice with staging in the development of characters, roles, and situations.

0FB0E6F0696147FF9CE93BB23FC66A16.description: Foundational Elements: Drama literacy is developed through knowledge and application of dramatic processes.
